I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help Mongolia respond to the 
gender impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak and associated measures in 
place to reduce rates of transmission, with the aim of mitigating negative consequences on 
women and the most vulnerable, particularly domestic violence. The TA will support the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) Strategy 2030 and its operational priority of accelerating the progress 
in gender equality.1 The TA is consistent with the objectives of ADB’s country partnership strategy 
for Mongolia, 2017–2020.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The COVID-19 pandemic remains a matter of serious concern and the Government of 
Mongolia has taken strong actions to respond to the outbreak and reduce the risk of community 
transmission. Following the initial outbreak of COVID-19 in the People’s Republic of China, the 
Mongolian National Security Council imposed restrictions on air travel, movement across borders, 
and school closures on 31 January 2020. Additional restrictions imposed during 21 February 
2020–22 March 2020 remain in place, including the cancellation of public events, mandatory 
quarantine measures, and restrictions on public venues and nonessential retail services. 
 
3.  COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound socio-economic impact. The crisis has affected 
men and women in different ways. While men appear to be at higher risk of infection and health 
impacts,3 women are facing greater hardship related to (i) their predominant role in health sector 
operations (in Mongolia they make up 82% of the health workforce); and (ii) their participation in 
microscale, family, and sole-entrepreneur-owned businesses, which have been affected by 
mobility restrictions and a consequent reduction in demand for services.4 ADB is conducting an 
ongoing rapid assessment of the impacts of the COVID-19 crisis on micro, small- and medium-
sized enterprises in Mongolia. Preliminary results reveal that 97% are facing negative impacts, 
with more than 90% of microenterprises reporting a sharp decline in revenues. COVID-19 mobility 
restrictions have impacted the unpaid and informal economy disproportionately, affecting women 
to a larger degree. Women who have inched out of poverty also risk falling back into vulnerable 
situations.5 
 
4.  The pandemic, including its severe economic impacts, have had a strong impact on 
domestic violence. Police records for the capital city of Ulaanbaatar indicated a 63% increase in 
reported cases from 1,900 during the first quarter (Q1) of 2019 to 3,100 during Q1 2020. Most of 
these cases (77%) included physical violence, about 90% were committed in a household setting, 
and women constituted 93% of the victims. During this time, police hotlines reported a 19% 
increase in calls and nongovernment-run helplines reported a 30% increase, while reduced 
mobility during the quarantine period and social distancing measures have resulted in victims of 
domestic violence having reduced options for support and counseling. It is likely that many have

been forced to remain at home with perpetrators. Nonetheless, the number of victims of domestic 
violence requesting shelter services increased by more than 50% from about 600 victims during 
Q1 2019 to more than 910 during Q1 2020. Domestic violence survivors suffer a range of serious 
physical and mental health consequences that require urgent responses, including emergency 
services, medical and psychological assessments, and immediate shelter options. As demand 
soars, shelters and one-stop service centers (OSSCs) nationwide are under strain. Challenges 
affecting emergency response services during the pandemic are described in paras. 5–6. 
 
5.  Lack of safety protocols and equipment for first response and shelter services. 
Mongolia has 14 shelters and 15 OSSCs that provide attention, counseling services, and short-
term safe accommodation to victims of domestic violence. All shelters and OSSCs have remained 
open during the COVID-19 crisis. However, these critical institutions lack all needed personal 
protective equipment (PPE) to attend to victims in a safe manner. Furthermore, no protocols are 
in place to reduce exposure of current residents to COVID-19 when new victims are received and 
sheltered,  and  the  facilities  have  no  budget  to  purchase  additional  decontamination  and 
disinfection  materials.  This  situation  puts  first  responders,  including  administrative  police 
assigned to attend to domestic violence cases, at heightened risk of possible exposure and 
contagion because of lack of basic PPE. 
 
6.  Inadequate capacity to respond to increased demand for hotline services. The 
channels to respond to increased demand have remained limited to a 24-7 police hotline (107) 
dedicated  to  domestic  violence  emergencies  and  one  domestic  violence  information  and 
counseling hotline run by the nongovernment organization National Center Against Violence 
(NCAV), which operates from 9 a.m. 6 p.m.6 The sole use of phone-based hotlines, which are 
unable to take multiple calls at once, limits the possibility of victims to reach services during the 
quarantine period, when they are largely confined indoors, sometimes in close proximity to 
perpetrators.  
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: adverse impacts of COVID-19 on women, 
particularly domestic violence, reduced. The TA will have the following outcome: critical response 
mechanisms for domestic violence maintained and preventive action enhanced.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Domestic violence response operations supported and shelter capacity 
increased. Under this output, the TA will support the safety of first responders during the 
pandemic through the procurement of (i) basic PPE, first aid kits, and disinfection items for all 14 
shelters and 15 OSSCs, as well as first responder police units across the country; (ii) three mobile 
ultrasound units for forensic examination of victims; and (iii) information technology hardware (e.g., 
desktop computers) to enhance digital counseling operations. 
 
 
6 To address the increase in the number of calls requesting information and counseling services during the COVID-19 
crisis, the United Nations Population Fund is covering the salary of two additional counselors for the NCAV’s hotline, 
ensuring it is operational 24-7 during June and July 2020. 
7 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
9.  Output 2: Prevention awareness and virtual counseling support services provided. 
The TA will increase the outreach capacity of government and nongovernment organizations to 
provide information and counseling services that address the needs of victims of domestic 
violence during the COVID-19 crisis, while increasing public awareness for effective prevention 
and increased reporting. This will be achieved through (i) supporting the expansion of information 
technology and digital infrastructure of the National Legal Institute (NLI) and the NCAV (e.g., using 
chatbots)  to  complement  existing  hotlines  and  counselling  services; 8  (ii)  designing  and 
implementing a multimedia communication campaign targeting people and families at risk of 
domestic violence with messages designed to prevent domestic violence in the context of the 
COVID-19 crisis; (iii) responding to increased demand for psychosocial counseling by enhancing 
capacity during the COVID-19 crisis through the provision of one additional counselor under the 
NCAV for the duration of the TA; (iv) organizing a hackathon to identify innovative digital solutions 
to address new forms of gender-based violence (GBV) such as cyberbullying;9 and (v) conducting 
virtual training programs for first responders on emergency response in cases of sexual violence, 
for shelter operators on stress management and mental health, and training of trainers for police 
psychologists. Output 2 is expected to generate valuable lessons for future operations to address 
domestic violence in Mongolia and Asia and the Pacific. 
 
10.  Output 3: Emergency response mechanism established. This output will support 
services for strengthening government sex-disaggregated data collection during the COVID-19 
crisis, including strengthening the database and data confidentiality mechanisms, monitoring 
capacity for rapid response, and capturing lessons and impact of TA emergency response actions 
to inform future operations to address domestic violence in the country. This output will be 
delivered through engagement of individual consultants for monitoring and evaluation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $440,000 of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix  2.  The  Government  of  Mongolia  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart  staff  remuneration,  meeting  venues,  value-added  tax  and  duty  exemptions  for 
imported goods and equipment to be procured under the TA, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s East Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants and monitor the quality of their work. The Ministry of Justice and Home 
Affairs (MOJHA) will be the executing agency, and the Secretariat of Coordination Council for 
Crime Prevention (SCCCP) under the MOJHA will be the implementing agency. The SCCCP will 
provide guidance to consultants and day-to-day oversight for the successful implementation of 
the TA. The SCCCP will form and chair a technical advisory group to peer-review the work of 
consultants. The technical advisory group will be composed of senior officials from the MOJHA 
and civil society organizations. It will meet at least three times during TA implementation. The NLI 
and the NCAV will confirm the contents of frequently asked questions that will be provided to the 
chatbots developed under the TA. 
 
 
8  Chatbots are artificial intelligence software applications based on natural language processing and used to conduct 
an on-line chat conversation via text or text-to-speech, in lieu of providing direct contact with a live human agent. 
9  Hackathon is an event in which people work together to create a solution to an existing problem using technology.

4

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm to deliver activities under outputs 
1 and 2. The firm will (i) provide content and message development and public awareness-raising 
activities;  (ii)  procure  medical  items  for  emergency  response  and  information  technology 
hardware and equipment to increase outreach and access to digital counseling services; (iii) plan 
and organize one hackathon; (iv) provide virtual training on sexual violence case management; 
and (v) provide virtual psychosocial and mental health training to staff of shelters and OSSCs, 
design stress management training materials, and deliver training of trainers for psychologists of 
police departments. ADB will engage individual consultants for monitoring and evaluation of the 
TA, and development of a knowledge product. Non-consulting services will be procured from a 
vendor to deliver chatbot development for the NLI and NCAV. Partial lump-sum contracts using 
performance (output)-based terms of reference will be used as appropriate. ADB will engage the 
consultants  and  non-consulting  services  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.10 ADB will evaluate the TA progress through semiannual review missions based on 
the performance targets and indicators defined in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 
1).  
 
15.  Procurement. The TA will procure items to increase the safety of first responders, staff 
and residents of shelters as well as to enhance the response capacity of forensic services and 
increase the outreach of counseling services. These items include PPE, mobile ultrasound units,

5 
infrared  thermometers,  disinfection  materials,  and  information  technology  hardware  and 
equipment. The consulting firm will undertake procurement under the guidance of ADB. The 
procured PPE and medical equipment will be handed over to the MOJHA, relevant ministries, and 
agencies, which will deliver them to the target beneficiaries (e.g., shelters, OSSCs, police 
departments, and the National Forensic Institute, under the MOJHA) during TA implementation. 
The TA will cover the delivery cost of goods to  14 shelters and 15 OSSCs through land 
transportation. Information technology hardware and equipment will be transferred to NLI and 
NCAV upon completion of TA activities.  Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy and 
its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
16.  Prevention awareness and promotion. The multimedia communication campaign will 
provide practical messaging and promote the GBV digital platform to address (i) increased 
exposure to risks, and the difficulty of GBV survivors and family members to access information 
and support because of quarantine-related lack of mobility; and (ii) increased risk of sexual 
violence and bullying for adolescents who are spending more time online. The communication 
campaign will drive traffic to the digital platform and lead people at risk of violence to the options 
available and accessible to them, depending on their digital capacities, including chatbots, mobile 
applications, private chat groups, websites (i.e., the NCAV and NLI websites), social media pages, 
and other channels, where they can download information.  
 
17.  Pilot testing of project approach. The TA will pilot test next-generation helplines for 
domestic violence cases with the establishment of chatbots, to efficiently increase access and 
reach of information, and counseling services for victims of domestic violence. As chatbots are 
programmed to communicate without the need of a human operator, their use is expected to 
contribute to increased availability of human operators to answer emergency and distress calls 
that require human interaction; nonemergency calls requesting information and counseling will be 
redirected to chatbots. The use of chatbots to increase outreach to victims of domestic violence 
has been tested in other contexts in Asia and the Pacific with initial good results.11  The chatbot 
will be programmed to discuss topics and content based on the input of national experts in the 
fields of domestic violence, crime prevention, and legal counseling. The content will go through a 
peer  review  process  involving  the  implementing  agency  and  leading  nongovernment 
organizations in the area of GBV. The pilot will focus on solutions to minimize risks, such as 
storing a minimum amount of users’ sensitive information; interaction between callers and the 
chatbot will be completely private and data will be encrypted on the server, with no storage or 
retention of any personal data about the user. The MOJHA has confirmed the sustainability of NLI 
chatbot operations and confirmed that chatbots and other software and digital outputs of the TA 
will be maintained by the NLI after TA completion. Digital contents piloted for the NCAV will be 
scaled up in digital platforms of the domestic violence hotline (107) maintained by the Municipality 
of Ulaanbaatar. Fees related to NLI chatbot usage licenses and all other related fees will be 
covered by the NLI and MOJHA upon completion of the TA. The pilot activities will not result in 
any potential adverse environmental and/or social impacts.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Addressing and Preventing Domestic Violence in Mongolia during 
the COVID-19 crisis, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
 
11 The beta version of the #MySis chatbot against GBV, developed by members of the police force in Thailand and 
launched in 2019 is an example.
